metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Abstract. 
Landslides are common on inclined areas of 
the seafloor, particularly in environments where weak 
geologic materials such as rapidly deposited, fine- 
grained sediment or fractured rock are subjected to 
strong environmental stresses 
such as earthquakes, 
large 
storm waves, and high internal pore pressures. Subma- 
rine landslides can involve huge amounts of material and 
can move great distances' slide volumes as large as 
20,000 km 3 and runout distances 
in excess of 140 km 
have been reported. They occur at locations where the 
downslope component of stress exceeds the resisting 
stress, causing movement along one or several concave 
to planar rupture surfaces. Some recent slides that orig- 
inated nearshore and retrogressed back across the 
shoreline were conspicuous by their direct impact on

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: INTRODUCTION

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Landslides occur under water as well as on land; in 
fact, they are surprisingly 
abundant on the seafloor. The 
morphology and mechanics 
of landslides above and be- 
low sea level have many similarities but significant dif- 
ferences as well. In this review we describe submarine 
landslides, tell how they can be recognized on the sea- 
floor, list the marine environments in which they occur, 
and discuss their causes and mechanics.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Landslides have been defined as the downward and 
outward movement of slope-forming materials, wherein 
shear failure occurs along one or several surfaces [Eckel, 
1958; Schuster, 1978]. The force of gravity plays an 
essential role in the mechanics. Rate of movement also 
has been included in the definition, requiring that land- 
slides move more than a foot or so a year [Gary et al., 
1974]. Most reported submarine landslides occur in un- 
lithified sediment, but some notable ones displace vol- 
umes of rock. Other related phenomena are flow pro- 
cesses 
such as creep [Silva and Booth, 1984], debris flows 
[Hampton, 1972], and turbidity currents [Kuenen and 
Migliorini, 1950]. In this review we consider some aspects

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
of high-density 
flows that evolve as part of the landslide

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: process.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
We will not dwell on terminology, but the reader 
should be aware that other names can be applied to what 
we here call submarine landslides: some combination of 
the words "marine" or "submarine" and slide or "slope

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
human life and activities. Most known slides, however, 
occurred far from land in prehistoric time and were 
discovered by noting distinct to subtle characteristics, 
such as headwall scarps and displaced sediment or rock 
masses, on acoustic-reflection 
profiles and side-scan so- 
nar images. Submarine landslides can be analyzed using 
the same mechanics principles as are used for occur- 
rences on land. However, some loading mechanisms are 
unique, for example, storm waves, and some, such as 
earthquakes, can have greater impact. The potential for 
limited-deformation 
landslides to transform 
into sedi- 
ment flows that can travel exceedingly long distances is 
related to the density of the slope-forming material and 
the amount of shear strength that is lost when the slope 
fails.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
failure" probably are the most common. More properly, 
however, the term "slope failure" refers to the process 
that creates landslides (i.e., a landslide occurs as a result 
of slope failure). Many times (in this review, for in- 
stance) submarine landslides are simply referred to as 
"slides." "Mass movement" is another term widely used 
to describe gravitationally driven sliding and flow.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Many, if not most, submarine landslides occur in the 
deep ocean, far from land, and those discussed in the 
literature tend to have specific academic interest, for 
example, their role in the evolution of the submarine 
landscape [e.g., O'Leary, 1993]. However, there are sev- 
eral impressive cases of practical interest, particularly 
near shore, when a slide has cut back across the shore- 
line in a populated area [e.g., Coulter and Migliaccio,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1966; Lemke, 1967; Auj•et et al., 1982] or when one has 
destabilized the foundation of a marine engineered 
structure [e.g., Bea, 1971; Sterling and Strohbeck, 1973]. 
Submarine landslides are being given increasing atten- 
tion as a cause of tsunamis, which can ravage coastal 
areas [Moore and Moore, 1984, 1988; von Huene et al., 
1989; Harbitz, 1992; Jiang and LeBlond, 1992].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Submarine landslides have been the subject of mono- 
graphs [Schwarz, 1982; Schwab et al., 1993a], confer- 
ences and their spawned special publications [Richards, 
1977; Bennett et al., 1982; Saxov and Nieuwenhuis, 1982; 
Lee, 1991], and topical reviews [Moore, 1977; Prior,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1984; Coleman and Prior, 1988; Lee, 1989; Lee et al., 
1993].

text:
FEATURES 
AND 
TYPES

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Landslides possess two essential features: a rupture 
surface (failure surface, slide surface) and a displaced 
mass of sediment or rock (Figure 1). The rupture surface 
is where failure took place and downslope movement 
originated, and more than one such surface may be 
present in a particular landslide complex. The displaced 
mass is the material that traveled downslope. It com- 
monly rests partly on the rupture surface, but it might 
have moved completely beyond it. Moreover, the dis-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
placed mass might remain intact, slightly to highly de- 
formed, or it might break up into distinct slide blocks. In 
some slides, all or part of the mass completely disinte- 
grates, producing a flow.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Following the terminology of Varnes [1978], the main 
scarp (or headwall scarp) is the upper part of the rupture 
surface vacated by the displaced mass. Crown cracks 
may exist within marginally stable material upslope from 
the main scarp, and minor scarps may exist within the 
displaced mass itself. The upslope terminus of the dis- 
placed mass is the head of the landslide, and the down- 
slope terminus is the toe. The toe region of the displaced 
mass can have an elevated surface created by resistance 
to downslope movement or rotation.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The rupture surface, particularly in mechanically ho- 
mogenous material, commonly is concave upward and 
scoop-shaped. Accordingly, motion of the displaced 
mass is rotational, whereby the original seafloor is back- 
tilted. Such slides are formally termed "rotational 
slides," or "slumps" (Figure 2). However, if mechanical 
inhomogeneities such as bedding planes control failure, 
then the rupture surface is more or less planar, move- 
ment is translational, and the landslide is called a "trans- 
lational slide" (Figure 3). Slidirig that occurs 
serially as 
numerous adjacent failures that progress upslope is 
termed "retrogressive."

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Enormous size is one way that submarine landslides 
can differ from subaerial landslides. The largest sub-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
aerial slides displace a few tens of cubic kilometers of 
material. For example, Crandell et al. [1984] described 
the 26-km 
3 Mount Shasta slide as the largest known 
Quaternary landslide on Earth, and Harrison and Falcon 
[1938] reported 
a slide of about 20-km 
3 volume 
in south- 
western Iran. By comparison, the largest submarine slide 
we are aware of, the Agulhas slide off South Africa, has

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
a volume of 20,000 km 3 and is purported 
to have oc- 
curred as a single slope failure event [Dingle, 1977]. 
Slides on the rocky flanks of the Hawaiian Islands 
[Moore et al., 1989] and the Storegga slide on the conti- 
nental slope off Norway [Kenyon, 1987; Bugge et al., 
1988] have volumes 
that exceed 
5000 km 3. The Storegga 
slide comprises three separate events, the largest of 
which is 3880 km 3, whereas some of the Hawaiian slides 
probably were single events.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The size and displacement of individual submarine 
slide blocks also can be impressive. Consider the Tusca- 
loosa Seamount, which is actually a detached block from 
the Nuuanu debris avalanche (a particular type of slide 
that consists 
of many individual blocks) off Oahu (Figure 
4 [Normark et al., 1993]). This "seamount" is 30 km long, 
17 km wide, and 1.8 km thick, and it rests 90 km from its 
source. Distal 
blocks of the Nuuanu 
debris avalanche 
traveled across the 4600-m-deep axis of the Hawaii 
Trough, then uphill to 4300-m water depth at their final 
resting place on the Hawaii Arch, about 140 km from 
their source. The Nuuanu slide must have been a truly 
monumental 
event! 
Submarine landslides can originate on nearly flat sur- 
faces. Carlson [1978] described a slide covering a 1080- 
km 2 area on a seafloor 
slope of 0.5 ¸ on the continental 
shelf off the Malaspina Glacier in the Gulf of Alaska. 
Field et al. [1982] reported a liquefaction failure, caused 
by an M = 7.2 earthquake, on the 0.25 ¸ declivity of the 
Klamath River delta, northern California. Prior and 
Coleman [1978] documented Mississippi River delta 
slides on slopes of 0.01 ¸.

text:
DOCUMENTATION, 
DISCOVERY, AND 
RECOGNITION

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
A few submarine landslides in historical times, 
namely, those that disrupted a populated shoreline or 
offshore engineered structures, were documented di- 
rectly. For example, the catastrophic slides in Seward 
and Valdez, Alaska, triggered by the great 1964 earth- 
quake were manifested almost immediately by roiling 
sea surface waves caused by failure of the steep sub- 
merged slopes of Resurrection Bay and Port Valdez, 
respectively [Lemke, 1967; Coulter and Migliaccio, 1966]. 
Shortly thereafter, the slides retrogressed across the 
shoreline, sinking sections of coastal land, harbor facil- 
ities, and other nearshore installations. Then tsunamis 
generated by the landslides repeatedly inundated the 
coastal areas. Many fatalities were caused by the slides 
and flooding. Comparison of the preearthquake and 
postearthquake 
bathymetry (water depths) defined the 
area affected by the slides and the thickness of displaced 
material.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
A 1888 slide in Trondheim Harbor, Norway [Andre- 
sen and Bjerrum, 1967], and a 1975 slide in Kitimat Arm,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
British Columbia, Canada [Prior et al., 1982a, b] had a 
similar sequence of offshore initiation, retrogression 
across the shoreline, and generation of tsunamis. The 
1979 slide at Nice, France, began underwater and gen- 
erated a tsunami. However, an associated coastal slide, 
which removed recently emplaced fill for a new port, was

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
not a retrogression 
of the original failure but was trig- 
gered secondarily, 
possibly by tsunami drawdown (low- 
ering of the water level when the trough of the tsunami 
reached the shoreline) [Auffret et al., 1982; Seed et al.,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 1988; Cochonat et al., 1993].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
An example of slightly less direct documentation is 
the experience associated 
with Hurricane Camille, which 
struck the U.S. Gulf of Mexico coastline in August 1969.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Figure 4. Side-scan sonar mosaic of the coalescing Nuuanu (off Oahu) and Wailau (off Molokai) debris 
avalanches, Hawaii. Individual displaced blocks appear as distinct light areas, generally becoming smaller 
farther from islands. From Normark et al. [1993].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Three petroleum platforms on the offshore areas of the 
Mississippi River delta were displaced and damaged, 
one irretrievably. Direct wind and wave forces were first 
proposed as probable causes of the damage, but post- 
storm surveys and soil mechanical analyses convincingly 
demonstrated that 20-m-high, hurricane-generated 
waves imposed forces on the seafloor that were strong 
enough to cause foundation-disrupting slides in water 
depths greater than 100 m [Bea et al., 1983].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Changes in seafloor depth, particularly in response to 
such convulsive events as earthquakes, have been used 
as the primary evidence for some submarine landslides. 
Shepard [1933] carefully compared lead line soundings 
in Sagami Bay both before and after the 1923 earth- 
quake and identified likely depth changes of more than

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

100 m in places. He suggested landslides as the cause of 
deepening.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Some submarine 
cable breaks have been attributed 
to 
landslides. The most celebrated example is the 1929 
Grand Banks earthquake, which is speculated to have 
caused failure of a large section of the continental slope 
off Newfoundland, simultaneously breaking six subma- 
rine telegraph cables between about 300-m and 3600-m 
water depth [Heezen and Ewing, 1952]. A consequent 
turbidity current broke several more cables to a distance 
of nearly 600 km from the epicenter. Reports of cable 
breakage by low-density turbidity currents and other 
sediment flows are numerous but beyond the scope of 
this review [see Heezen and Ewing, 1955; Krause et al., 
1970].

Figure 5. Submarine landslides in the North Arm of Saguenay Fjord, Quebec, Canada, shown on a 
multibeam bathymetry map, a side-scan sonar image, and an acoustic-reflection profile. Note position of 
slumps along the eastern sidewall, compression ridges in the side-scan sonar image, and direction of two 
lateral spreads (debris flows) A and B. If only acoustic profiles of debris flows A and B were available, as 
shown at bottom, an incorrect interpretation of their relative movement could easily have been made, as if 
debris flows had moved from both sides of fjord rather than down the fjord as is evident in multibeam 
bathymetry map. Note that the flow or failure surface is easily identifiable at about 25 m beneath the seafloor.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
In contrast to the aforementioned examples, most 
landslides 
on the seafloor 
occurred 
unobserved 
or in 
prehistoric times and, being masked by the cover of 
water, are discovered with remote-sensing instruments

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
such as acoustic-reflection profilers, swath-bathymetry 
systems, or side-scan sonar imagers (Figure 5). Direct 
observation via submersibles or bottom photography 
sometimes is done as a follow-up to discovery by remote 
sensing [e.g., Greene et al., 1991]. Some landslides are 
deduced strictly on the basis of deformed sediment in 
cores [Gutmacher and Normark, 1993].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
An impressive display of submarine landslides ap- 
pears on long-range side-scan sonar images of the Ha- 
waiian Islands Exclusive Economic Zone. Complete so- 
nar image coverage of the seafloor, extending 370 km 
offshore from Hawaii to Midway, reveals 68 major slides 
that extend seaward from the volcanic ridge [Moore et 
al., 1989, 1994a; Normark et al., 1993]. The abundance

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
and areal extent of these landslides 
were not realized 
before the sonar surveys, although the existence of some 
slides was controversially 
speculated by Moore [1964] on 
the basis of offshore bathymetric features (large blocks) 
and onshore topographic features (high coastal cliffs). 
Because of their rugged morphology the slides appear as 
light-toned areas of high backscatter in the side-scan 
images (see Figure 4). Two types of slides are distin- 
guished on the basis of morphology: slumps and debris 
avalanches. Slumps consist of relatively undisturbed 
masses that slid along curved rupture surfaces, with the 
bulk of the material not traveling beyond the flank of the 
volcano. Slumps can be deep seated; for example, the 
rupture surface of the Hilina slump, south of the island 
of Hawaii, is believed on the basis of seismicity to reach 
a depth of 10 km. In contrast to slumps, debris ava- 
lanches have a well-defined headwall scarp (amphithe- 
ater), and the transported rock and sediment are broken 
into numerous discrete blocks, some of which move 
great distances (>200 km). Slumps likely move short 
distances episodically. For example, geodetic measure-

on the Missis- 
sippi River delta, Louisiana. From Prior and 
Coleman [1978]. Reproduced with permission of 
Taylor & Francis, Washington, D.C. All rights 
reserved.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
ments 
before 
and 
after 
the 
1975 M 
= 
7.2 
Kilauea 
earthquake indicated 3.5 rn of subsidence and 8 m of 
horizontal movement of coastal land that probably is 
part of the Hilina slump. Debris avalanches probably 
move rapidly during a single episode, as w.as previously 
mentioned for the Nuuanu debris slide. Many of the 
high coastal cliffs (pali) on the islands now are inter- 
preted as the headwalls of submarine landslides, 
whereas they previously were interpreted as erosional or 
tectonic in origin.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Another excellent display of submarine landslides is 
on sonar images of the Mississippi 
River delta. Slumping 
on the delta was first proposed by Shepard [1955] as an 
explanation for the valleys he detected on bathymetric 
charts. Later, Prior and Coleman [1978, 1982] imaged 
selected areas of the delta and found abundant evidence 
for slope failure, although the term "slope" barely ap- 
plies to some unstable areas where the seafloor declivity 
is only 0.01 ø. The best sonar images of landslides clearly 
show headwall sc. 
arps and associated crown cracks, hum- 
mocky seafloor, and compressional ridges (Figure 8) 
[Prior and Coleman, 1978, 1980]. The most subtle slides 
simply show subparallel, 0.3- to 3-m-high scarps of shal- 
low, retrogressive 
slumps (Figure 9). Sediment flows are 
associated 
with many of the slides. These' composite 
features commonly consist of a bowl-shaped source area 
with subsidence and slumping, a chute that directs sed- 
iment flows downslope from the source area, and a distal

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Figure 9. Linear features attributed to shallow slumps, Mississippi River delta, Louisiana. From Prior and 
Coleman [1980].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
area of overlapping deposits [Prior and Coleman, 1982]. 
Similar slides have been reported on other deltas [e.g., 
Prior et al., 1986].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Probably the least direct method of documenting 
submarine landslides is from tsunami deposits, using the 
rationale that sudden movement of large submerged 
blocks of rock or sediment can displace enough seawater 
to generate a large wave, or tsunami, that erodes marine 
and coastal sediment and deposits it inland. Submarine 
landslides have long been suspected as a cause of tsuna- 
mis [Shepard, 1933; Gutenberg, 1939], and as was de- 
scribed above for the 1964 Alaska earthquake, local 
slide-generated tsunamis have been observed. As an 
example of indirect documentation, Moore and Moore 
[1984] mapped a gravel-to-boulder deposit to an eleva- 
tion of 326 m on the south side of the Hawaiian 
island of 
Lanai and attributed it to a tsunami. This deposit con- 
tains offshore-derived 
limestone 
and the skeletons 
of 
reef organisms, and its age is estimated at 105,000 years. 
Three beds are superimposed, each consisting of two 
subunits. Moore and Moore [1988] interpreted each bed 
as the product of a separate tsunami and the subunits as 
the products of run-up and backwash of each wave. It 
has been speculated that either the Clark submarine 
slide off Lanai [Moore and Moore, 1988] or the Alika 
phase 2 slide off Hawaii [Normark et al., 1993] was the 
source of the tsunamis. Suspected slide-related tsunami 
deposits also have been mapped on the Hawaiian islands 
of Molokai, Oahu, Maui, and Hawaii [Moore et al.,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf
Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Another example 
of an inferred tsunami 
deposit 
from 
a submarine landslide is afforded by the conspicuous, 
areally extensive, landward thinning bed of silty fine sand

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 19449208, 1996, 1, Downloaded from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/95RG03287 by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [12/03/2025]. metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
that lies within otherwise clayey deposits of coastal east- 
ern Scotland. The bed originally was interpreted as a 
storm deposit by Smith et al. [1985], but other docu- 
mented regional historical storm deposits differ in that 
they are areally discontinuous and most detritus is 
moved seaward. Alternatively, Dawson et al. [1988] and 
Long et al. [1989] interpreted the bed as a tsunami

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
deposit from the second Storegga submarine landslide, 
partly on the basis of physical resemblance to a tsunami 
deposit from the 1960 Chile earthquake [Wright and 
Mella, 1963]. The bed, which ranges to more than 70 cm

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
thick and contains abundant marine diatoms, has been 
radiocarbon dated at 7,000 years. The ages of sediment 
above and below the bed differ by about 300 years, 
implying deposition by a short-lived event. Harbitz [1992] 
modeled the alleged Storegga tsunami and postulated 
run-up elevations of 3 to 5 m, about the same as those 
deduced from the deposits.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
ENVIRONMENTS 
AND 
CAUSES

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Rapid accumulations of thick sedimentary deposits, 
sloping seafloor, and high environmental stresses 
are the 
conditions most commonly associated with submarine 
landslides. Certain geologic environments tend to have 
these conditions, and consequently, submarine land- 
slides are common there. Despite these concise, general 
statements, the situation is complex: many specific fac- 
tors contribute to submarine landslides, and they occur 
in a diversity of environments.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Slope failure is so common in five environments that 
they can be designated as submarine landslide territory:

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
(1) fjords, (2) active river deltas on the continental 
margin, (3) submarine canyon-fan systems, 
(4) the open 
continental slope, and (5) oceanic volcanic islands and 
ridges. Common, but not unique, to all of these environ- 
ments is the presence of an inclined seafloor where the 
force of gravity persistently acts to pull sediment and 
rock downslope. Mechanically, a landslide occurs when 
the downslope driving stress, which nearly always in- 
volves more than gravity, exceeds the resisting strength

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The situation in Resurrection Bay is unusual with 
regard to the variety of environmental loads that con- 
tributed to slope failure. However, most of these condi- 
tions have been documented in other fjords: seismic 
loading in Port Valdez [Coulter and Migliaccio, 1966]; 
low tides in Kitimat 
Arm 
and Howe 
Sound in British 
Columbia, Canada [Terzaghi, 1956; Prior et al., 1982b] 
and in Orkdalsfjord and Trondheim Harbor in Norway 
[Bjerrum, 1971]; artesian pressure in Orkdalsfjord [An- 
dresen and Bjerrum, 1967]; and the load of man-made 
structures in Kitimat Arm [Prior et al., 1982b]. Addi- 
tional factors, not documented in Resurrection Bay, 
include bubble phase gas, whose expansive pressure can 
reduce the effective stress in sediment while disrupting 
the sediment structure and may have contributed to 
slope failure in Kitimat Arm [Prior et al., 1982b], and the 
load of areally concentrated sediment deposition due to 
river control, as in Port Valdez [Coulter and Migliaccio,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: of the slope-forming material.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: Fjords

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Fjords are glacially eroded valleys that have been 
inundated by the sea. There is typically a steep-fronted 
delta at the head of a fjord, fed by a sediment-laden 
stream that drains the diminished glacier that eroded the 
valley [Syvitski et al., 1987]. Rapid deposition on the

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
delta can outpace the expulsion of pore water, causing a 
state of underconsolidation and consequent low static 
shear strength. Furthermore, rock flour sediment is 
characteristically susceptible to strength loss when ex- 
posed to repeated loading by waves or earthquakes. The 
sidewalls of fjords are steep, and the deposits of sedi- 
ment that settle from suspension are subject to frequent 
small failures [Farrow et al., 1983]. The side entry deltas 
that build outward 
onto the sidewalls also can fail fre- 
quently because of rapid deposition and steep slopes 
[e.g., Prior et al., 1981].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Fjords attract human settlement because they provide 
protected ports and staging areas in otherwise rugged 
terrain. Unfortunately, the failure-prone fjord deltas 
commonly are the only flat land available for the loca- 
tion of communities and industry. The threat of re- 
peated delta slope failure from natural causes or human 
activities poses a danger that sometimes cannot be mit- 
igated with engineering methods, so some of the other- 
wise desirable land must be abandoned. In Seward, for

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Resurrection Bay, a fjord in southern Alaska, was 
mentioned previously as the site of the catastrophic 
submarine landslides that damaged the city of Seward in 
1964. The setting and conditions serve to demonstrate 
the complex interplay of factors that can influence slope 
failure in a fjord. The great 1964 earthquake certainly 
triggered these landslides because the first landslide 
effects occurred within a minute of the start of ground 
shaking. The earthquake's strong seismic accelerations 
repeatedly imposed dynamic forces that added to the 
large downslope component of gravitational force on the 
steep-fronted deltas of the Lowell and Resurrection 
Rivers. Furthermore, the repeated loading caused a 
buildup of pore pressure in fine-grained sediment that at 
least partially supported the weight of the grains, de- 
creasing the frictional resistance (effective stress) at 
grain contacts and thereby decreasing the strength. The 
long duration of strong ground shaking (3 to 4 min) 
contributed to the great extent of slope failure. Poste- 
arthquake investigations revealed high artesian pressure 
within confined aquifers of the delta, which also de-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Point source entry of sediment from a river mouth 
onto the continental margin can create localized deltaic 
deposits where submarine slope failure commonly, but 
not always, strongly modifies the seafloor. The slides on 
the Mississippi River delta have been studied particu- 
larly intensively, and the conditions that cause them are 
fairly well understood and applicable to some other 
deltas [e.g., Sterling and Strohbeck, 1973; Coleman and 
Prior, 1978; Prior and Coleman, 1980; Bea et al., 1983;

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
creased the effective stress between grains [Shannon and 
Wilson, Inc., 1964; Lemke, 1967], and the steeply sea- 
ward dipping strata within the delta may have contained 
planes of weakness that enhanced the tendency for 
downward 
and outward 
movement 
of sediment. 
The 
unusually low tidal levels at the time decreased stability 
by removing the hydrostatic support that previously bal- 
anced the weight of the internal pore water. Finally, the 
extra load imposed by waterfront artificial fill and such

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 19449208, 1996, 1, Downloaded from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/95RG03287 by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [12/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
installations as railroad docks and petroleum storage 
tanks added to the driving force.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 1966] and Howe Sound [Terzaghi, 1956].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
example, a strip of coastal land about 300 m wide was 
designated as high risk and restricted to parkland use 
after 1964. In Valdez, geologic and engineering studies 
indicated a susceptibility to future slope failure so ex- 
tensive as to necessitate 
relocation 
of the entire town to 
a site 5.5 km away on the geologically more stable 
Mineral 
Creek fan.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: Active River Deltas on the Continental Margin

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Coleman et al., 1993]. Mississippi River sediment is de- 
posited rapidly in large volumes on the delta; as much as 
6 million 
metric 
tons of sediment 
is delivered 
to the 
coast annually, 
and accumulation 
rates exceed 1 m yr -• 
in places. The fine-sand bed load accumulates mainly at 
or near the migrating distributary mouths as a relatively 
high density deposit that differentially loads the under- 
lying finer-grained sediment. The silt-clay suspended 
load accumulates mostly on a platform beyond the dis- 
tributaries. The fine-grained deposits distinctively have

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: very high water content and are extremely underconsoli-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
dated. Furthermore, decay of organic material forms 
expansive interstitial gas (primarily methane). Conse- 
quently, the static shear strength can be so low that these 
substantial thicknesses of weak sediment move down the 
nearly flat delta surface under the small gravitational 
driving force, particularly after major floods and high 
sediment discharges 
from the river. The previously men-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
consolidation. Also needed, however, are environmental 
processes, such as storms or earthquakes, that can gen- 
tioned hurricane-generated 
waves are another well-doc- 
umented cause of slides. Elevated and reduced pressure 
beneath crests and troughs, respectively, imparts re- 
peated loads on sediment beneath a passing wave train

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[Henkel, 1970]. The magnitude of these combined in- 
stantaneous-loading and progressive-weakening pro- 
cesses is a function of water depth, wave height, wave- 
length (which can be mor e significant than wave height, 
according to Bea [1971]), and number of cycles (of the 
order of 1000 for large storms). Loads eventually can 
exceed sediment strength, theoretically to water depths 
of more than 100 m for large hurricane waves [Henkel,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Submarine canyons incise many of the world's conti- 
nental slopes and rises, and the presence of voluminous 
submarine fans at their mouths attests to their impor- 
tance as conduits of sediment transport from the shallow 
to the deep ocean. Canyon walls can be tall and steep, so 
slope failure is at least intuitively likely. Furthermore, 
canyon heads act as traps for mobile, sandy shelf sedi- 
ment, and deposits have been documented to disappear 
abruptly after storms and earthquakes [Marshall, 1978; 
forded a rare opportunity to document the effects of a 
known forcing event on shelf deltaic sediment [FieM et 
al., 1982; Field, 1993]. Immediately after the earthquake, 
commercial fishermen reported new scarps on the pre- 
viously smooth, gently sloping (0.25 ø ) delta surface. The

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1970], and indeed, the platform destroyed during Hur- 
ricane Camille was in 100-m water depth. Elsewhere, 
rapid deposition of silt-sized sediment and the action of 
large storm waves and earthquakes have been cited as 
the reasons for abundant slope failure on the Huanghe 
(Yellow River) delta, China [Prior et al., 1986].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
An M - 7.0 earthquake that struck the Klamath 
River delta, northern California, in November 1980 af-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
area had been surveyed just 1 year before the earth- 
quake, and these scarps did not appear in subbottom 
profiles. However, they did appear, in addition to pres- 
sure ridges, sand boils, collapse depressions, and gas 
seeps, when the area was resurveyed about a month after 
the earthquake and twice again within the following 
year. The surveys identified a 20-km-long, 1- to 4-km- 
wide zone of earthquake-induced liquefaction failure, 
less than 15 m thick, in about 60-m water depth.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Some major deltas do not display evidence of slides. 
Such absence of evidence does not preclude previous 
failure in these deposits because waves and burial can 
obscure the failure features. However, the absence of 
such features likely indicates that slope failure is less 
frequent or extensive in these deltas. Most notable is the 
delta of the Changjiang (Yangtze River) in China, which 
is the fourth largest contributor of suspended sediment 
in the world, delivering 
about 0.5 x 10 9 tons of sediment 
annually. Although significant deltaic deposits occur 
there, as well as pockmarks resulting from expulsion of 
biogenic gas, the seafloor is otherwise featureless

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[Butenko et al., 1985]. Continental shelf deposits derived 
from the Zhu Jiang (Pearl River), China [Liang and Lu,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1986], and the Columbia River, Washington [Nittrouer 
and Steinberg, 1981], also appear to be featureless. Evi-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 19449208, 1996, 1, Downloaded from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/95RG03287 by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [12/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
dently, a combination of circumstances is needed for 
slope failure to occur on deltas. High sedimentation 
rates are needed so that a sufficiently thick bed of 
sediment can accumulate. Relatively low permeability 
(fine-grained or plastic sediment) can allow high pore 
water pressure to be retained, thereby producing under-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
erate 
shear stresses in the sediment 
that exceed 
the 
shear strength. These stresses can be augmented by 
shear strength degradation during repeated loading, 
such as seems to be particularly common in glacially 
derived sediment. Finally, the configuration of the con- 
tinental shelf, including its declivity, can influence the 
stability of deltas. The interaction of all of these factors, 
rather than any single factor alone, ultimately deter- 
mines whether instability will occur.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: Submarine Canyons

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Malouta et al., 1981], possibly as a result of landslide-like 
movement, although current erosion may be more prev- 
alent. Slow, gravity-driven, creep-like motion of canyon 
head sediment has been observed [Shepard and Dill,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1966]. In deeper water, clear evidence of slides exists on 
submarine fans, particularly on the relatively steep 
walled and fine grained levees of fan valleys [e.g., Walker 
and Massingill, 1970].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Slope failure may be the dominant process that 
sculpts and enlarges certain submarine canyons, as Carl- 
son and Karl [1988] speculated for the gigantic canyons

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
along the Beringian margin west of Alaska, on the basis 
of widespread appearance of hummocky mounds, dis- 
placed blocks, and back-rotated slump masses on acous- 
tic-reflection profiles and distorted sediment in cores. 
They speculated that the canyons originated by subma- 
rine landsliding during the low sea level of the Pleisto- 
cene glaciation and attributed the cause of the slides to 
high pore water pressure in rapidly deposited fluviogla- 
cial sediment, gas charging, and external forces such as 
from earthquakes and large waves.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Slope failure caused by internally derived seepage 
forces appears to be particularly important in the evo- 
lution of regularly spaced, headless submarine canyons: 
those that do not breach the shelf break and are isolated 
from downslope erosive flows, as from rivers [Orange 
and Breen, 1992; Orange et al., 1994]. Analysis of the 
headless canyons of the convergent Cascadia and His- 
paniola margins, the passive U.S. Atlantic margin, and 
the carbonate platform of the western Florida margin

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
indicates that increasing hydraulic-head gradient, caused 
by tectonic compression or from artesian sources at the 
canyon head, promotes slope failure and causes upslope 
canyon growth. The presence of a canyon causes an 
increase in the local head gradient near the canyon floor, 
decreasing the gradient to some distance away and es- 
sentially preventing slope failure and canyon formation 
nearby. This self-organization can lead to a statistically 
regular spacing of canyons on the continental slope.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Open Continental-Margin 
Slopes 
Steep regional seafloor declivity is intrinsic to the 
intercanyon areas of open continental-margin slopes 
(i.e., the continental slope proper and marginal basin 
slopes); slopes of 30-6 ø are typical, and steeper slopes 
are common [Shepard, 1963]. Thus a relatively high 
tendency exists for gravitationally driven downslope 
movement. The literature is replete with reports of slides 
on the open continental-margin slopes of the world's 
oceans, from polar [e.g., Grantz and Dinter, 1980] to 
equatorial [e.g., Moore et al., 1976] latitudes and in 
convergent [e.g., Hampton and Bouma, 1977], divergent 
[e.g., Booth et al., 1993], and transform [e.g., FieM and 
Edwards, 1980] tectonic settings. The following addi-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
tional 
locations 
and references 
demonstrate 
the wide 
geographic distribution of these slides off the continents 
and larger islands: western United States [Haner and 
Gorsline, 1978], eastern United States [Uchupi, 1967; 
McGregor and Bennett, 1977; Embley and Jacobi, 1986],

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Gulf of Mexico [McGregor et al., 1993], Puerto Rico 
[Schwab et al., 1993b], eastern Canada [Stanley and Sil- 
verberg, 1969; Morin and Pereira, 1987], arctic Canada

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[Hiscott and Aksu, 1994], Mexico [Normark, 1974], Cen- 
tral America [Baltuck et al., 1985], South America 
[Moore et al., 1970; Li and Clark, 1991], Australia [Jen- 
kins and Keene, 1992], New Zealand [Lewis, 1971; Barnes 
et al., 1991], Japan [Jacobi and Mrowzowski, 1979], Korea

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[Chough et al., 1991], Taiwan [Chen and Tian, 1982]; 
Burma (Myanmar) [Moore et al., 1976], Africa [Jacobi,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1976], Israel [Almagor and Garfunkel, 1979], Greece 
[Lykousis, 1991], Italy [Trincardi and FieM, 1992], Spain 
[Alonso et al., 1990], Portugal [Roberts and Stride, 1968], 
and Norway [Bugge et al., 1988].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Analyses have shown that the force of gravity typically 
is not great enough to be the sole cause of failure on 
continental margin slopes [e.g., Ross, 1971; Almagor and 
Wiseman, 1977; Hampton et al., 1978] except in some 
places of high tectonic steepening [Ferentinos et al.,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1981]. In fact, the controls on most identified slides are 
obscure, and earthquake shaking commonly is specu- 
lated, essentially by default, to be the cause, although it 
has been documented for only a few events, for example, 
the Grand 
Banks slide.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Some slides seem to be associated with the effects of 
low or rapidly changing sea level, as Trincardi and Field

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[1992] suggested for the Licosa slide in the Tyrrhenian 
Sea. They observed that the slide mass consists of a 
relatively coarse grained, rapidly deposited, lowstand

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 19449208, 1996, 1, Downloaded from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/95RG03287 by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [12/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
progradational wedge that moved along a downlap sur- 
face that may be covered with weak, highstand sediment. 
Lykousis [1991] identified weak sapropel layers formed

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
during Pleistocene anoxic events as constituting the fail- 
ure surface of slides near the Hellenic 
Arc. 
Gas hydrate disassociation is another phenomenon, 
commonly associated with sea level change, that proba- 
bly drives slope failure. Gas hydrates, also called clath- 
rates, are mixtures of ice and methane interstitial to 
sediment grains. They form beneath the seafloor under 
well-defined conditions of temperature and pressure,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
and they contain a huge amount of free-gas equivalent: 
170 volumetric 
units of free methane 
at standard 
tem- 
perature and pressure in one volumetric unit of gas 
hydrate [Kvenvolden et al., 1984; Sloan, 1990]. As was 
demonstrated by Kayen and Lee [1991, 1993], lowering 
of sea level causes partial disassociation 
of gas hydrate, 
formation of bubble phase gas, and increase of pore 
pressure at the base of the remaining, possibly imper- 
meable hydrate. Thus the sediment may fail at the base 
of the hydrate, and Kayen and Lee identified this situa- 
tion in seismic-reflection profiles from the Beaufort Sea 
slope, Alaska. Similar cases have been reported on the 
continental slope off northern California [FieM and Kv- 
envolden, 1985] and the U.S. Atlantic coast [Carpenter,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 1981; Popenoe et al., 1993].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Some slides are associated with weak mobile 
salt or 
mud. For example, Almagot [1980] described deep- 
seated slides on the continental slope off northern Sinai- 
southern Israel that occur over unusually thick accumu- 
lations of Messinian evaporites. He concluded that 
downslope flow of the buried evaporites causes failure of 
the overlying Nile River-derived clastic deposits. The 
Cape Fear slide off North Carolina, which is thought to 
have been caused by disassociated 
gas hydrate, also has 
two large salt diapirs near the main headwall that might 
have aided failure by steepening the seafloor and frac- 
turing the sediment [Popenoe et al., 1991]. Carlson et al. 
[1993] suggested 
that slides on the margin of the Umnak 
Plateau in the southern Bering Sea are a response to 
slope steepening during emergence of mud diapirs.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: Oceanic Volcanic Islands and Ridges

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Discovery of the numerous giant landslides on the 
flanks of the Hawaiian Ridge revealed that slope failure 
can be a major destructive process on oceanic volcanoes. 
As was summarized by Moore et al. [1994a], the discovery 
prompted published descriptions 
of slides on many other 
volcanoes and ridges. They cited references to slides on 
Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean, the submerged 
flanks of Mounts Etna and Stromboli in Italy, the Mick- 
elson Ridge, the Emperor, Mapmakers, and Marcus- 
Wake Seamount groups, and the Marquesas Islands. 
Holcomb and Searle [1991] also speculated, on the basis

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
of island morphology (high coastal cliffs, stellate perim- 
eter), that landslides are common on, and perhaps char- 
acteristic of, the flanks of many oceanic islands, atolls, 
guyots, and seamounts. They presented side-scan sonar

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
images that show probable submarine debris avalanches 
on Tristan de Cunha and E1 Hierro 
Islands. Slides have 
reduced the area of some islands by as much as by half.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The young, submerged Loihi Volcano, south of Ha- 
waii, has landslides on more than half of its surface

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[Moore et al., 1989]; thus slope failure develops early in 
the evolution of these edifices. Moore et al. [1989] pre- 
sented evidence that the larger landslides occur late in 
the shield-building stage, but as was pointed out by 
Normark et al. [1993], the young volcanoes Mauna Loa

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
and Kilauea, still well into their shield-building phase, 
have landslides on their flanks. Landsliding seems to 
occur throughout most of the growth history of the 
volcanoes and perhaps even after dormancy.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The cause of these giant landslides is cryptic. Large 
earthquakes generated on the slide surface have oc- 
curred in association with slide movement, but these 
earthquakes probably are an effect rather than a cause of 
slippage. The volcanic rift zones that conduct magma 
away from summit reservoirs form the headwalls of 
slides, and failure might be related to magma injection, 
although the question of cause and effect still remains. 
For example, Moore et al. [1989] reported that the 1975 
Kilauea eruption apparently was triggered by movement 
of the Hilina slump.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Other Causes of Submarine 
Landslides 
Other processes 
in addition to those mentioned above 
in the context of specific environments are suspected to 
cause submarine landslides. Faults, aside from the earth- 
quakes associated with them, have been suggested to 
control some failures. Dillon et al. [1993] concluded that 
massive displaced limestone blocks on the Blake Escarp- 
ment, east of Florida, are restricted to the southern 
segment, where faults occur; faults do not exist to the 
north. Strong currents erode the entire length of the 
escarpment, and large, fault-bounded blocks slide of[ 
when the southern cliff becomes oversteepened. Else- 
where, Hampton et al. [1978] identified faults at the base 
of two slides on the upper continental slope in the Gulf 
of Alaska and suggested that removal of support due to 
fault movement, perhaps in conjunction with earthquake 
shaking and tectonic steepening, caused the slides to

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: move.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Another tectonic process, tectonic compression at 
subduction zones, was proposed by Li and Clark [1991] 
as one of several causes of slumping in lithified sediment 
on the landward wall of the Peru-Chile Trench. They 
presented a scenario for slope failure that is closely 
linked 
to subduction 
of the Nazca 
Plate beneath 
the

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Chilean margin, with attendant faulting, earthquakes, 
and slope steepening. They added that elevated pore 
pressure from dewatering in response to tectonic com- 
pression abets slope instability, similar to the explana- 
tion of evenly spaced canyons advanced by Orange et al.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf
Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Oversteepening of the upper part of tall carbonate 
slopes might lead to failure. Schlager and Camber [19861

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 19449208, 1996, 1, Downloaded from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/95RG03287 by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [12/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
noted that tall (>600 m) submarine slopes composed of 
carbonate sediment tend to be steeper than their siliclas- 
tic counterparts and approach a limiting angle of about 
29 ø. The reason for oversteepening 
of these sedimented 
slopes is attributed to cementation, growth of reef com- 
munities, and dissolution. Gravity eventually limits the 
degree of steepness.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Extremely slow downslope flow of sediment, termed 
"creep," has long been studied in relation to degradation 
of subaerial slopes [e.g., Casagrande and Wilson, 1951; 
Mitchell et al., 1968]. Of interest to this discussion, 
creep 
can lead to failure, either of the creeping sediment itself 
or of overlying rafted sedimentary layers. Within the 
creeping sediment, failure occurs at lower, persistent 
stress than the static strength [Casagrande and Wilson,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1951; Sherifet al., 1979]. Although proof that creep is a 
significant process on the seafloor remains elusive, both 
experiments and theory suggest that thick deposits on 
steep slopes can weaken and fail by this process [Silva 
and Booth, 1984].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Finally, biologic processes 
can influence slope stabil- 
ity. Some observational and speculative studies have 
been conducted on the weakening and destabilization of 
submarine slopes by burrowing organisms [Dillon and 
Zimmerman, 1970; Hecker, 1982] and on the strengthen- 
ing effects of bacteria, fungi, and other microfaunas

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[Meadows et al., 1994]. However, the magnitude of bio- 
logic effects, particularly in activating large-scale slope 
failure, is unknown.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
SLOPE FAILURE 
MECHANICS

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Quantitative analysis of slope failure mechanics can 
delimit the particular environmental conditions that 
cause failure. Also, the relative stability of different sites 
and the potential for future slope failure can be evalu- 
ated. Such information is useful for assessing 
geologic 
hazards in areas considered 
for offshore construction 
or 
other applications, such as waste disposal.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: Limiting Equilibrium

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
As was mentioned previously, landslides are initiated 
when the shear stress oriented downslope (driving shear

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
stress) exceeds 
the shear strength (resisting stress) of the 
slope-forming material (Figure 10). Definition of the 
shear strength requires selection of a failure criterion 
that represents its physical characteristics. 
Most gener- 
ally used is the Mohr-Coulomb failure criterion,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
'rf = c' + ({y-u) tan 
(1)

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
where 1-f is the shear strength (i.e., the shear stress at 
failure), c' is the effective cohesion, 4•' is the friction 
angle, {y is the stress acting normal to the failure surface, 
and u is the pore water pressure. The term ({y-u) is the 
effective normal stress, generally summarized as {y'. For 
intact rocks, the cohesion can be very high (500-10,000

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
kPa), but for most sediment 
the cohesion 
is much lower 
or even negligible. 
Interestingly, 
the friction coefficient 
of intact rock and sediment and the joint friction of dry, 
smooth rock discontinuities 
generally have about the 
same range: 200-45 ø , depending 
on the composition 
of 
the geologic 
material (e.g., very soft weathered 
rocks to 
very angular talus slopes). 
The Mohr-Coulomb 
failure 
criterion indicates a linear relation between shear 
strength 
and effective 
stress. 
If the effective 
stress 
acting 
on the sediment element is reduced, for example, by 
pore pressure 
increase, 
an equivalent 
reduction 
in the 
shear strength results.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: Shear Stresses

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Three types of downslope 
driving stresses 
are signif- 
icant with regard to submarine 
slides: 
gravity, 
seismically 
induced stress, and storm-wave-induced 
stress. Evalua- 
tion of slope stability requires an estimate 
of the driving 
shear stress 
and a comparison 
with the appropriate 
shear 
strength 
of the slope-forming 
material. Many studies 
of 
limiting equilibrium 
of submarine 
slopes 
have been con- 
ducted [e.g., Morgenstern, 
1967; Hampton et al., 1978; 
Prior and Suhayda, 
1979; Edwards 
et al., 1980; Lee et al., 
1981; Almagor and Wiseman, 1982; Schwab and Lee, 
1983; Sangrey, 
1983; Bet et al., 1983; Lee and Edwards, 
1986].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
To evaluate submarine-slope stability during the 
planning and design stages for submarine structures, 
detailed site-specific 
analyses 
must be performed 
includ- 
ing mapping 
with side-scan 
sonar and acoustic-reflection 
profilers, 
sediment 
sampling 
and laboratory 
testing, 
in- 
place testing 
of sediment 
and rock, detailed 
bathymetric 
charting, and two- or three-dimensional 
numerical 
anal- 
yses of the factors of safety of the slopes 
against 
failure 
from the various possible 
loading mechanisms. 
Details 
of most of the techniques that would be needed to

For rock masses,

such a slope is completely

text:
The result of this discussion is that for a semi-infinite, 
purely frictional (cohesionless) 
slope, the slope declivity 
at failure is the friction angle of the sediment. Such a 
declivity is termed the "angle of repose." If sand is slowly 
poured into a pile (as in an hourglass), it typically will 
steepen to a particular angle, which will be approxi- 
mately equal to the friction angle. The concept of an 
angle of repose need not be reserved exclusively for 
gravitational loading. Indeed, as slopes are repeatedly 
exposed to storm wave or earthquake loading or both, 
they also will tend toward a certain steepness that is 
related to the local storm wave or seismic environment. 
We can then speak of the storm wave or seismic angle of 
repose, which is lower than the static angle of repose 
represented by (7).

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Seismic loading. Earthquakes generate horizontal 
and vertical accelerations that induce corresponding 
shear and normal 
stresses in the sediment. 
The shear 
stress can drive the sediment to failure and responds 
most strongly to horizontal acceleration. The response 
of the Earth to the propagation of seismic waves is 
complex and not easily described with a few parameters. 
However, a simplified approach that has been used with 
some success 
is to assume that a given earthquake can be 
represented by a characteristic horizontal acceleration k 
(expressed 
as multiples of the gravitational acceleration 
#). In addition, the horizontal acceleration is assumed to 
be applied over such a long period of time that the 
induced stresses can be considered constant. This ap- 
proach [Morgenstern, 1967; Lee and Edwards, 1986], 
which is termed "pseudostatic," leads to a seismically 
induced downslope shear stress 'r s given by

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf
Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: where •/is the total sediment density (•/' + density of

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: seawater).

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
This downslope shear stress can be balanced against 
an appropriate shear strength to determine the relative 
stability of a given slope. Because earthquakes occur 
over a short time span and because the loading is cyclic,

sediment. Lee and

text:
factor that accounts for the difference 
between 
the ef- 
fects of isotropic-loading conditions in the laboratory 
and anisotropic loading in the field and is typically equal 
to about 0.8; and A• is the cyclic-strength 
degradation 
factor, which relates to the proportion of the shear 
strength that remains after earthquake shaking and re- 
sulting pore water pressure increase. The factor A•, 
which is measurable by cyclic strength testing in the 
laboratory, ranges from 0.5 or less for silt to more than

consolidation stress for normal consolidation, S, which is 
measurable in the laboratory, ranges from 0.3 or less for

ratio (of maximum 
past effective stress to present overburden effective 
stress), and m is a sediment property, typically about 0.8. 
The quantity (OCR) m is set equal to 1 for thick units of 
normally consolidated sediment, that is, those with hy-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Lee and Edwards [1986] investigated a series of sub- 
marine slides that were likely initiated by earthquakes

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
along the seismically active margins of California and 
southern Alaska. Using the stress formulations given by 
(8) and (9), and sediment properties measured in the 
laboratory on core samples, they solved for k in the area 
within and near known failures. They found that a 
pseudostatic 
acceleration k of 0.13 to 0.14 # corresponds 
to the boundary between failed and unfailed sediment 
and represents the initiation of failure under the envi-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
ronmental conditions prevalent on these margins. Note 
that the factor k used by Lee and Edwards is empirical 
and not equal to the peak ground acceleration for a 
particular earthquake.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Storm wave loading. Large storm waves generate 
adjacent zones of relatively high and low pressure be- 
neath crests and troughs, respectively. These alternating 
zones, in turn, generate zones of relatively high shear 
stress halfway between the crests and troughs. Because 
the waves propagate past a particular point, the induced 
shear stress ('rw) varies cyclically and may alternate in 
direction. Seed and Rahman [1978] presented a version 
of the following equation to estimate the induced shear 
stress as a function of wave characteristics 
and depth in 
the sediment 
column:

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
,w/•l'Z = sin ot + X•IwH/E•I'L cosh (2xd/L)], 
(10)

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
where z is the depth below the sediment-water interface, 
ot is the slope gradient, 3'w is the density of seawater, H 
is the wave height, L is the wavelength, and d is the 
water depth.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Because the cyclic loading exerted by storm waves is 
much like that caused by an earthquake, a strength 
formulation similar to that given by (9) typically can be 
applied. The appropriate value of the factor A r used for 
storm waves will differ from that used for earthquakes 
because a storm would typically have a greater duration

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
and include many more cycles of loading [e.g., Schwab 
and 'Lee, 1993]. Clearly, storm waves are capable 
of 
causing sediment failure only in relatively shallow water, 
for example, on the continental shelf and uppermost 
continental slope.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
POSTFAILURE 
EVOLUTION 
OF SUBMARINE

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: LANDSLIDES

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Postfailure 
evolution 
of a submarine 
landslide 
corre- 
sponds to the development of velocity vectors in the 
displaced mass. Depending on the in-place stress, sedi- 
ment properties, and morphology, the failed mass either 
will stop a short distance along the rupture surface or 
will evolve into a flow with a relatively large travel

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
distance. The distribution of displacements and veloci- 
ties throughout a flowing sediment mass somewhat re- 
sembles that in flowing viscous fluids. Innumerable shear 
surfaces may exist throughout the flow, and they may be 
transient 
and invisible. Slides and flows are end-mem- 
bers of a series, and many actual failures involve ele- 
ments of both.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The postfailure evolution of submarine landslides has 
been investigated in a few studies. Koning [1982] inves- 
tigated marine sand flows and showed that the tendency 
to flow is related to the magnitude of sediment porosity 
in excess of a particular critical value. Einsele [1990] 
speculated that analogous to quick clay (e.g., the Rissa 
(Norway) and St. Jean Vianney (Qu6bec, Canada) slides

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 19449208, 1996, 1, Downloaded from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/95RG03287 by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [12/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[Edgers, 1981; Locat and Demers, 1988; Locat et al,, 1990; 
Locat, 1992]), in which sediment was totally remolded

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
and flowed out of the slide area, marine sediment also 
tends to mobilize if the water content is greater than a 
critical value (the liquid limit) to a substantial depth in 
the sediment column. Both of these studies were limited 
because they did not include evaluation of the stress and' 
sediment strength conditions responsible for driving sed- 
iment flows on actual slopes. For example, Middleton 
and Hampton [1976] and Edgers and Karlsrud [1982] 
considered the quantitative dynamics of flows after they 
are generated, but they evaluated the initiation of the 
flows from a qualitative point of view only.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
A distinction between flows and less mobile types of 
landslides can be drawn in other ways. For example, 
Whitman [1985] contrasted disintegrative and nondisin- 
tegrative failure. In nondisintegrative failure, deforma- 
tions occur during a transient loading event (e.g., inertial 
movements during an earthquake), but little deforma- 
tion continues after the event. In contrast, in disintegra- 
tive failure the transient loading event produces such a 
loss of shear strength that the remaining strength is less 
than the gravitational force. Poulos et al. [1985] defined 
a condition of liquefaction as nearly the same as Whit- 
man's disintegrative failure. Such a definition of lique- 
faction differs somewhat from that used by Seed [1979] 
and other investigators, 
who typically applied the term to 
the response of loose sand to earthquake loading. Hence 
to avoid confusion, we prefer to use Whitman's termi- 
nology (i.e., disintegrative failure, as opposed to lique- 
faction).

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Poulos et al. [1985] developed the notion of a steady 
state of deformation as a way of quantifying the devel- 
opment of disintegrative failure. As a result of the large 
strain sustained during the initial loading event, sedi- 
ment tends to expand or contract, or to change its 
effective stress from its initial state to a critical, steady 
state [Poulos, 1981]. Once in this steady state, the sedi- 
ment continues to deform at constant volume (i.e., at a 
constant void ratio or the related state variable, porosi- 
ty), constant velocity, and constant effective stress under 
the influence 
of a constant 
external 
shear stress. On a 
plot of void ratio (or water content or liquidity index) 
versus either log effective stress or log shear strength, the 
curve describing the steady-state condition commonly is 
a straight line (the steady-state line) over a moderate 
range of effective stress (Figure 13). The steady-state 
approach, which is based on extensive laboratory studies 
and follows the work of Casagrande [1936], is consistent 
with the concepts of critical-state soil mechanics

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: [Schofield and Wroth, 1968].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Initial (prefailure) void ratio/effective-stress 
condi- 
tions can be plotted on a steady-state diagram to disclose 
whether disintegrative failure of the sediment is possible

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
(Figure 13). If the initial-state data points fall above the 
steady-state line and if loading is undrained, then the 
pore pressure will increase, and the effective stress 
within the sediment will decrease, during failure. Thus

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Cyclic loading from an 
earthquake or storm

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Figure 13. Two ways in which sediment state can change 
during undrained failure induced by a transient loading event 
such as an earthquake or a storm.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
the mobilized steady-state shear strength will be lower 
than the initial-state shear strength, and the first crite- 
rion for flow is satisfied. Because the sediment 
fabric 
tends to collapse in this condition, the condition is 
termed "contractive." 
According to Whitman [1985] and 
Poulos et al. [1985], only contractive sediment can pro-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
duce a disintegrative type of failure. In contrast, if the 
initial-state data points fall below the steady-state line, 
the sediment will tend to dilate, decreasing the pore 
pressure. The effective stress will then increase until 
failure occurs. Such a "dilative" sediment cannot pro- 
duce a disintegrative failure unless its fabric somehow 
expands and is converted to a contractive state. Schwab 
and Lee [1988] suggested 
that some flow failures on the 
continental shelf of Alaska may have been produced by 
sediment that expanded during long-duration storm 
wave loading.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Lee et al. [1988] investigated five onshore landslides 
that were induced by rainfall. By comparing initial-state 
and steady-state data, they found an association 
between 
initial-state data points falling above the steady-state 
line and disintegrative failures. Initial-state data points 
that fell near or below the steady-state line corre- 
sponded to slow moving, nondisintegrative failures.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The steady-state approach can be illustrated for the 
marine environment through three field investigations. 
Figure 14 shows high-resolution subbottom profiles of 
three submarine-landslide 
deposits demonstrating vari- 
ous degrees of mobilization. The two least mobile fail-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 19449208, 1996, 1, Downloaded from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/95RG03287 by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [12/03/2025].
