metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
ures are classified as slumps: the Icy Bay-Malaspina 
slump (Figure 14a) and the Humboldt slump (Figure 
14b). The Icy Bay-Malaspina slump [Carlson, 1978; Lee 
and Edwards, 1986] occurred in glacial-marine rock flour 
on the continental 
shelf in the eastern Gulf of Alaska. 
This slump, which measures 20 x 90 km (along the 
coast) occurred on a slope of 0.5ø-1.0 ø. Individual slump 
blocks rotated along shear surfaces with about 5 to 10 m 
of displacement. 
The Humboldt slump [Lee et al., 1981; 
Lee and Edwards, 1986] occurred in clayey silt off Eu-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
reka, California. This slump, which measures 6 x 15 km, 
occurred on a 1.5 ø slope. Individual slump blocks rotated 
along shear surfaces with 10 to 20 m of displacement.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
A more 
mobile 
feature 
is classified as a flow: for 
example, the Gaviota mudflow (Figure 14c) [Lee and 
Edwards, 1986], which occurred in silty clay in the Santa

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Barbara 
Basin off southern 
California. 
The 
mudflow 
initiated on a 4 ø slope, evacuated a scar, and continued 
more than 1 km downslope. The flow stopped at the

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
transition to a 1 ø slope, leaving a thick, hummocky 
deposit lacking internal acoustic reflectors. An even 
more mobile feature that also is a flow occurred south of 
the Palos Verdes Peninsula, Los Angeles County, Cali- 
fornia (Figure 6). The top of the headwall is near the 
shelf break and extends approximately 10 km along the 
coast. Displaced sediment rests on the base of the slope 
and on the basin floor beyond the base. Where the 
sediment flowed out onto the basin floor, it has a jum- 
bled surface and lacks internal bedding. Maximum 
runout distance is about 10 km.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The first three 
of these failures 
was evaluated 
to 
determine the sediment properties that relate to land- 
slide evolution [Lee et al., 1991]. For two of the three 
failure sites (Icy Bay-Malaspina slump and Gaviota 
mudflow), initial-state void ratio conditions plot above 
the steady-state 
line. According to Poulos et al. [1985], 
data points above the steady-state line imply that flows 
are possible if two further conditions are met: (1) a 
disturbing event, such as an earthquake or major storm, 
occurs and shears the sediment 
to the extent 
that it 
reaches the steady state, and (2) after the disturbing 
event the downslope shear stress due to gravity is greater 
than the steady-state shear strength that has been mo- 
bilized. The occurrence of landslides, as documented on 
high-resolution subbottom profiles (Figure 14), implies 
that the sediment has been extensively strained, almost 
certainly to the point of reaching the steady state. Ac- 
cordingly, the first of these conditions is satisfied.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
For the Icy Bay-Malaspina slump, Lee et al. [1991] 
found that the steady-state shear strengths exceeded the 
steady-state (gravitational) driving shear stress by more 
than a factor of 10. Recall that the Icy Bay-Malaspina 
slump involved relatively limited shear deformation 
along the defined failure surfaces (Figure 14a). This 
limited deformation could have occurred during the 
loading event that caused failure, likely an earthquake 
[Lee and Edwards, 1986]. After the initiating event, the 
sediment strength was too large to allow further down-

text:
Figure 15. Estimated steady-state (gravitational) driving 
shear stress and steady-state shear strength versus subbottom 
depth for the Icy Bay-Malaspina slump and the Gaviota mud- 
flow. The Icy Bay-Malaspina slump could not develop into a 
disintegrative failure because the steady-state shear strength 
was much greater than the driving shear stress. The Gaviota 
mudflow did develop into a disintegrative failure because the 
driving shear stress on the initial 4 ø slope exceeded the steady- 
state shear strength. Flow stopped where the slope steepness 
flattened to 1 ø because the shear stress on this slope was too 
low to overcome the steady-state shear strength.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
slope movement or flow under the influence of gravity 
alone.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
For the Gaviota mudflow, the slope ranges from 1 ø to 
4 ø across the study area, implying several profiles of 
steady-state driving shear stress, each a function of slope 
steepness. The line defining the steady-state shear 
strength passes through the range of the shear stress 
lines (Figure 15). This steady-state 
shear strength is less 
than the driving stress for subbottom depths down to 30 
m if the slope is 4 ø and is greater than the driving stress 
for all subbottom depths if the slope is less than 1.5 ø. 
Accordingly, after initial failure during a transient load- 
ing event, the steady-state shear strength is less than the 
gravitational shear stress on the 4 ø slope where initial 
failure occurred. Large-scale deformation and flow 
could continue under the influence of gravity. Ignoring 
inertial effects, the flow would proceed only until the 
driving stress became too small to overcome the steady- 
state shear strength. Such a situation would occur at the 
point where the slope drops to 1.5 ø , according to Figure

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: 15, which is what appears to have occurred in the field.

text:
The mudflow proceeded down the 4 ø slope, evacuating 
an exposed scar. At the base of the steeper slope, where 
the gradient flattens to 1 ø, the flow stopped and did not 
proceed out onto the floor of the Santa Barbara Basin 
(Figure 14c).

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
For the Humboldt slump the initial-state data points 
fall approximately on the steady-state line. This result 
implies that flows are unlikely, regardless of stress con- 
ditions on the slope, unless the fabric somehow expands 
during loading.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
In addition to the aforementioned examples, Kayen et 
al. [1989] used the steady-state approach to evaluate 
both 
landslide 
initiation 
and 
the 
transformation 
of 
slumps into flows on the gently sloping summit and steep 
flanks of a Pacific Ocean seamount. As is shown by these 
studies, the concepts of Whitman [1985] and Poulos et al. 
[1985] are valuable because they can lead to a method- 
ology for determining which landslides transform into 
flows. Specifically, a loss of shear strength must occur in 
the sediment mass during failure, and the resulting 
strength must be smaller than the downslope gravita- 
tional stress. The failed sediment 
mass will then accel- 
erate downslope and tend to disintegrate and flow.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
POSTFAILURE 
DYNAMICS

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Once failure 
occurs and the slide mass moves down- 
slope, the dynamics of motion become of interest. Sev- 
eral models of motion dynamics have been constructed. 
The first model was that of Morgenstern [1967], who 
proposed a'one-dimensional analytical solution for the 
movement of submarine landslides. Morgenstern's 
model was based on soil mechanics principles, with pore 
water pressure as the major element responsible for the 
very low apparent coefficient of friction. Later, Hutchin- 
son [1986] proposed a one-dimensional model that also 
was based on plastic behavior of the failed mass, al-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
though he added a pore pressure dissipation term, based 
on the theory of consolidation, with the coefficient of 
volumetric consolidation and the hydraulic conductivity

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
as the parameters. In both models the one-dimensional 
approach required that the failed mass move as a plug 
with no internal velocity gradient. Observations of debris 
flows indicate clearly that shearing takes place in the 
failing mass much as in laminar flows. This aspect was 
considered by Hampton [1972], Suhayada and Prior 
[1978], and Edgers and Karlsrud [1982], who modeled 
submarine debris flows as a fluid with mixture properties 
similar to those of a Bingham viscous fluid.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
With the recent granular-flow studies on dry sand 
[Hutter and Savage, 1988; Savage and Dai, 1992; Wilde- 
muth and Williams, 1985], saturated sandy mixtures or

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf
Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Chen and Ling, 1993; Coussot and Piau, 1994], and snow 
avalanches [Irgens, 1988], it became clear that the me-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
chanics of these mass movements is complex and that 
the constitutive equation for sediment deformation must 
include both plastic and viscous parameters. Such an 
approach was proposed by Norem e! al. [1990] for sub- 
marine landslides, as follows:

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

flow, % is the yield strength (analogous to cohesion in 
the static case), •r is the normal stress, ru is the pore 
pressure ratio u/•H, d)' is the friction angle, rn is the 
Bingham viscosity, and p is the density of the fluid 
mixture, which is affected by the shear rate and disper- 
sive pressure. The r value is believed to range from 1 to 
2 for macroviscous 
and inertial flows, respectively. This 
equation has been solved for a two-dimensional model, 
as shown in Figure 16, using the finite-difference method 
[Norem et al., 1990]. Although this model is limited in its 
ability to describe the full flow mechanism, it may be 
able to predict the final shape of the failure deposit, 
which for submarine landslides can be mapped well by 
using recently developed techniques [Lee et al., 1993]. 
The model of Norem et al. has been applied to the 
Sokkelvik submarine landslide in Norway (Figure 17). 
According to this model, the failed mass reached a peak 
velocity 
of 18 rn s -• a short distance 
downslope 
from its 
origin.

between the observed and predicted positions of the 
slide debris because the numerical 
model does not take 
into account hydrodynamic-drag forces acting on the 
moving mass. If such drag forces are considered, a 
smaller runout distance would be predicted. Therefore 
an important feature that needs to be considered for 
submarine landslides is the role of drag forces exerted by 
the surrounding seawater, both at the front and on the 
top of the moving mass. To evaluate these drag forces, 
Norem et al. [1990] proposed using an equation devel-

text:

stress at any point x along the plane is defined by

text:
rapidly to a constant value for x > 4000k. For the 
Sokkelvik landslide (Figure 17) they estimated that the 
resistance to flow resulting from drag forces on the 
surface was about 30% of the shear resistance at the

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: base of the slide.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
To date, only limited applications of numerical mod- 
eling have been used to predict the two-dimensional flow 
field and the final deposit shape for submarine land- 
slides. Indeed, in many ways the submarine environment 
is still enigmatic. For example, considering the numer- 
ous submarine landslides off the Hawaiian Islands, no 
explanation is possible yet for the great mobility of the 
debris, which traveled hundreds of kilometers, appar- 
ently without rotation of the debris blocks during the 
flow. Similar observations have been made for large 
subaerial landslides [Erismann, 1979; Melosh, 1986], sug- 
gesting that laminar flow was maintained throughout the 
event. If hydrodynamic-drag 
forces were to account for 
30% of the bed resistance in some slides, the very low 
apparent coefficient of friction at the base of the slide 
should have been exceeded by the hydrodynamic-drag 
forces, which in turn would cause rotation of the debris 
blocks.

text:
the local relief downslope and, commonly, travel a long 
distance (see Table 1). In this section we illustrate the 
mobility of submarine landslides. Because only a few 
references are available concerning this type of mobility

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
[e.g., Norem et al., 1990], we must rely in part on studies 
of subaerial landslides and debris flows to provide a 
reference 
framework. 
To illustrate the mobility of some submarine land- 
slides, we use the approach of Scheidegger 
[1973] for 
subaerial landslides [see Edgers and Karlsrud, 1982], 
which originates from the work of Heim [1932]. Schei- 
degger [1973] constructed a simple model, based on 
friction only, to illustrate the mobility of subaerial land- 
slides. An adaptation of Scheidegger's model is illus- 
trated in Figure 18, which shows a failed mass that 
traveled downslope until it stopped at some distance 
away from its origin. The model considers dry granular 
material and does not take into account pore pressure,

where v is the velocity, # is the gravitational accelera-

text:
Scheidegger 
[1973] showed that integrating (14) over 
the distance s in the runout zone yields the relation

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf
Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
where h is the elevation difference between the top of 
the failed mass at the point of initiation and the top of 
the failed mass in the depositional zone, and L is the

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
distance from the origin. Scheidegger indicated that the 
slope angle [3 could then be assumed to equal the fric- 
tion angle q>' and suggested that the coefficient of fric- 
tion decreases substantially if the volume of material is 
more than 100,000 m 3.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
To use this approach, we compiled the runout char- 
acteristics of various submarine 
landslides 
of different 
origins and material types (Table 1). Values of tan [3, 
equivalent to the h/L ratio in Figure 18, are plotted in 
Figure 19 as a function of volume. On the same figure, 
upper-bound values derived from the data of Edgers and 
Karlsrud [1982] and an average value for subaerial land-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
slides from Scheidegger 
[1973] also are plotted. Remem- 
ber that this approach is based on a purely frictional 
material with no water interaction. Such an approach is 
valid for many large landslides [Melosh, 1986; Erismann,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
1979] in which water is absent or other mechanisms 
are 
active (fluidization, air cushioning, etc.). Such circum- 
stances certainly are not valid for submarine landslides, 
although gas and heat can be present. The plot in Figure 
19 shows that submarine landslides can be much larger 
than subaerial 
landslides 
and that volcano-related 
sub-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
marine 
landslides 
can have extreme 
runout 
distances. 
This information was not available either to Scheidegger 
or to Edgers and Karlsrud. Indeed, most of the literature 
on subaerial landslides and their mechanics appears to 
ignore the abundance and diversity of very large subma- 
rine landslides. This model is useful for slides on which 
information is available regarding elevation in the 
source and depositional areas. If more morphologic in- 
formation were available, an approach that focuses on 
displacement of the center of mass, as proposed by 
Cruden [1988] and Cruden and Hungr [1986], could be 
used.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
Figure 19 shows considerable scatter in the data 
points. Such scatter is expected, considering the diversity 
of environmental 
conditions 
in which submarine 
land- 
slides occur lEdgers and Karlsrud, 1982]. For example, 
channelization will produce a longer runout distance 
than unconfined flow. Also, obstacles will limit runout.

text:
Figure 19. Compilation of known submarine-landslide ratio 
of height to runout distance (h/L) versus volume of failed 
mass. Upper-bound values from Edgers and Karlsrud [1982] are 
given with the upper curve proposed for submarine landslides 
and the lower curve for quick clay slides (subaerial), along with 
the average value for subaerial landslides proposed by Schei- 
degger [1973].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The precision of the geomorphic description is also a 
significant factor. For example, Edgers and Karlsrud 
[1982] proposed a runout distance for the Grand Banks 
landslide of more than 800 km, whereas Prior and 
Coleman [1979] estimated a distance of only 110 km. 
Also, mass movements can be initiated in different ways. 
From the preceding section, we would expect that land- 
slides initiated in contractive sediment by wave action or 
earthquakes could reach longer runout distances than if 
the sediment were dilative. All the data appear to fall 
within the maximum range of values observed for sub-

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
aerial landslides and the failure of quick clay, which 
behaves as a Bingham fluid when remolded [Locat and 
Demers, 1988; Locat, 1995].

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
For the Hawaiian 
submarine 
slides the runout 
data 
nearly agree with those for subaerial landslides. Al- 
though these runout distances are very great, the h/L 
ratio is much greater than those for other large subma- 
rine landslides, such as the failure that occurred off the 
Grand Banks. The Hawaiian landslides behave like gran- 
ular rock avalanches in which the presence of water does 
not appear to be a factor that limits runout distance.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The data plotted in Figure 19 and listed in Table 1, if 
taken alone, indicate that submarine landslides have a 
low coefficient 
of friction. 
More 
recent research on the 
dynamics of mass movements [Hungr and Morgenstern, 
1984b; Hutter and Savage, 1988; Sassa, 1988] supports 
the idea that the value of tan [3 is useful but represents 
only the apparent coefficient of friction. Hungr and Mor- 
genstern [1984a] showed that even at high velocity, the

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text: dynamic coefficient of friction of a granular material is

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
almost the same as its static value. Other factors, appli- 
cable to submarine landslides, that can be postulated to 
account for the low values of tan [3 include elevated pore 
water pressure [Suhayda and Prior, 1978; Cruden and 
Hungr, 1986], elevated gas pressure [Kayen and Lee,

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
199i; Coleman et al., !993], and dispersive 
pressure 
[Bagnold, 1954, 1956] (applied by Norera et al. [1990] and 
Moutte et al. [1992]).

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
CONCLUDING 
REMARKS

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The manifold 
publications 
Cited in this report dem- 
onstrate 
that submarine 
landslides 
have been studied 
extensively. 
They have been identified 
worldwide, 
and 
they are known to be particularly common in certain 
environments. Recently developed wide-range swath ba- 
thymetric and side-scan instruments have made mapping 
of landslides 
more feasible and identification 
less ambig- 
uous than when only depth-point 
and line profiling tech- 
niques were available. Submarine landslides can be truly 
enormous, they can initiate on extremely low slopes, and 
they can move as if the water were not present. At least 
the basic elements of landslide initiation and postfailure 
behavior are understood, and it is obvious that several 
environmental stresses, seldom acting individually, con- 
tribute to slope instability. Less is known of the timing 
and recurrence interval of slides in a particular region. 
Accurate and economical determination of in-place 
properties, especially at depth beneath the seafloor, re- 
mains a problem in evaluating slope stability.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
The perspective of this report is from a scientific, 
rather than an engineering, point of view; it is also 
regional rather than site-specific. However, we intend 
the information contained herein as a starting point for 
mitigating the effects of landslides on offshore and 
coastal development.

metadata.source_doc: Reviews of Geophysics - 1996 - Hampton - Submarine landslides.pdf

text:
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS. We appreciate the helpful 
manuscript reviews by Robert Kayen, Martin Lee, Gregory 
Moore, William Ryan, and Robert Schuster.
